results.title: The Prospector
results.creator_credit: Children's Library and Crafts Movement Australiaz and Daryl Hill
results.brief_description: A man who has been “panning” for gold all his life in the vicinity of the Hill End goldfields gives an account of how the fossicking is actually done, and gives something of the history of Hill End itself.

results.title: The Prophets: Pont-Aven, the Nabis and Toulouse-Lautrec
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Cypres, International Film Bureau and Pierre Alibert
results.brief_description: Works of the “Nabis” - Vuillard, Serusler, Ranson, Roussel and Bonnard, whose basic principle was that the picture is not a description and should differ from the model. Compares the “Nabis” with Toulouse-Lautrec to show how both confirmed change in painting and helped open the way for modern painting. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.title_for_label: The Prophets: Pont-Aven, the Nabis and Toulouse-Lautrec

results.title: The Prophecies of Nostradamus
results.creator_credit: Antonia Benedek and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Mysteries (Ep 3)”.
In this film, Henry Lincoln breaks through the barriers set up by innumerable interpreters which has obscured the real Nostradamus and reveals what the man himself was like and what he actually wrote.

results.title: The Promised land
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “American visions”.
In the second program of the series, Robert Hughes explores how religion was to have a fundamental impact on the shaping of American culture. The first European settlers presented the New World as both paradise and hell, a source of plunder, and a center of religious fantasy. During the early years of what Hughes describes as an invasion of North America by Europeans, the Spaniards conquered New Mexican Indian pueblos and citadels such as Acoma and set up their own architectural forms. These came to include the adobe Catholic church and the art of the santos- crude and vivid and designed to drive out the ancient gods from Indian minds. Meanwhile, seventeenth-century New England began to create a severe culture of practicality and moral rigor produced by Puritanism and later Utopian sects such as the Shakers. Then the Germans came, the Pennsylvania Dutch, the Quakers. In an America conceived as a religious refuge, a sanctuary for what Abraham Lincoln called the “half-chosen people,” what was used bears the print of what was believed. This pervaded the early paintings, crafts and buildings of Puritan America. The program concludes with the emergence of a culture which could begin to be called American. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: The Promise of the city
results.brief_description: A study of the slums and shanty towns of Bogota, Columbia, showing the transformation of squatter settlements into permanent, steadily improving neighbourhoods. Many of the problems encountered here arise from the rapid increase in population and intensive settlements of migrants in the city. Lacking in adequate training for most of the jobs offered, migrants have settled on government land in Bogota and attempt to eke out an existence in poor conditions.

results.title: The Promise = Das Versprechen [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Eberhard Junkersdorf, Bioskop Film, Odessa Films, JMH Productions and Margarethe Von Trotta
results.brief_description: In 1961, shortly after the construction of the wall, Sophie (Corinna Harfouch/Meret Becker), Konrad (August Zirner/Anian Zollner) and several friends attempt to escape to West Berlin through an underground sewer system. Due to a moment of hesitation, Konrad is left behind in East Berlin. Over the next thirty years they will make attempts at being reunited, but will only succeed in four brief encounters; one of them resulting in the birth of their son. The strength of their feelings is unable to overcome the years of separation, the bureaucratic obstacles and the simple fact that they are living in diametrically opposed worlds. When the wall finally comes down in November 1989, the two countries are reunited geographically, but the two lovers are left pondering their chances of emotional reunification. Also with Eva Mattes and Otto Sander. In German with English subtitles. Reference: The Promise - Interview with Margarethe von Trotta by Pauline Adamek (3/121995). Goethe Institut (Montreal). Online. http://www.goethe.de/uk/mon/entrotta.htm

results.title: The Progressive era: reform works in America
results.creator_credit: Maurice Schonfeld and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Evaluates the aims and achievements of the group of American reformers known as the progressives. Depicts social and economic conditions that prevailed during the progressive era, 1890-1919. Describes the election of 1912, when all three presidential candidates ran as progressives.

results.title: The Professor's new clothes
results.creator_credit: Janet Bell, Stephen Ramsey, Channel 4, ABC-TV (Australia) and Film Australia
results.brief_description: ABC “Science Show” host, Robyn Williams, narrates this fascinating program on the ethics of scientific research and a recent case of major fraud involving internationally renowned geologist, Professor V. J. Gupta, of Punjab University. Gupta’s falsification of research spread over a 25 year period in 400 published papers. The fraud was unearthed due to the tireless detective work of Australian paleobiologist, Professor John Talent, of Macquarie University. The scandal generated by his findings resonated at a national level with the Indian government imposing a media ban in a cover-up attempt, but Talent’s perseverance meant the truth was finally made public.
